choices.text: Apo E1
Apo E2
Apo E3

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apo E4

 

Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD)

 

The chromosome 19 genetic region that codes for apolipoprotein E (ApoE) has a significant impact on the likelihood of developing AD. Based on two amino acid polymorphisms, there are three alleles (alleles 2, 3, and 4). Individuals with the 4 allele are overrepresented in communities of patients with AD because the 4 allele's dosage decreases the age of illness start and raises the risk of AD. According to estimates, this locus accounts for around 25% of the risk for developing sporadic AD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E1: Not commonly recognized in the context of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Option B. Apo E2: Known to be protective against Alzheimer’s, potentially by promoting a more effective clearance of amyloid-beta from the brain.

 

Option C. Apo E3: The most common allele and considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apo E4 allele is a well-documented genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, influencing the disease's onset and severity. Understanding the genetic risk factors like Apo E4 is crucial for early intervention strategies and for personalizing treatment and management plans for at-risk populations.

 

Apo E2 is protective for Alzheimers disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg + IgM anti-HBc

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Hepatitis B is diagnosed based on specific serological markers. The presence of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen (IgM anti-HBc) indicates an acute infection. Here’s a detailed explanation:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen is present on the surface of the Hepatitis B virus and indicates an active infection. It is one of the first markers to appear in the blood following infection.
  2. IgM anti-HBc (IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen): The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection, as IgM is produced early in the immune response. This marker is crucial in differentiating acute from chronic infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgG anti-HBc: The presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates a past or chronic infection. It is not specific for acute infection.

 

Option C. anti-HBs: The presence of anti-HBs antibodies indicates recovery and immunity from Hepatitis B infection, either due to past infection or vaccination.

 

Option D. HBeAg: This antigen indicates active viral replication and high infectivity but does not differentiate between acute and chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc, which indicate an active and recent infection.

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ion exchange

 

Ion exchange chromatography is a highly effective method for detecting glycosylated hemoglobin (Hb-A1c). This technique separates hemoglobin molecules based on their net charge differences. Hb-A1c, which is glycated hemoglobin, has a different net charge compared to non-glycated hemoglobin. As a result, it can be quantified accurately using ion exchange chromatography. This method is widely accepted and used in clinical laboratories for monitoring long-term blood sugar control in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography relies on the specific binding between a molecule of interest and a ligand immobilized on a chromatography column. While affinity chromatography can be used for various biomolecular separations, it is not the method of choice for detecting Hb-A1c. The affinity column would need to have a specific ligand that binds selectively to Hb-A1c, and this approach is less commonly employed compared to ion exchange chromatography for this purpose.

 

Option C. Isoelectric focussing: Isoelectric focussing is a technique that separates proteins based on their isoelectric points (pI), which is the pH at which a protein carries no net electrical charge. While this method can separate different hemoglobin variants based on their pI values, it may not be as precise as ion exchange chromatography for quantifying Hb-A1c specifically, as it relies on charge differences related to pI rather than glycation.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique for separating molecules based on their charge and size differences in an electric field. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin variants, including Hb-A1c, based on their charge differences. However, it may not provide the same level of specificity and accuracy as ion exchange chromatography when it comes to quantifying Hb-A1c.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

 

Ref- https://www.japi.org/v264/hba1c-result-does-it-depend-upon-the-testing-methods-

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

In a standard normal distribution, the data is symmetrically distributed around the mean, forming a bell-shaped curve known as the Gaussian distribution. This distribution is characterized by the following properties:

 

  • The mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and located at the center of the curve.
  • The curve is bilaterally symmetrical, meaning if a perpendicular line is drawn from the top of the curve, it divides the graph into two equal halves.

 

One of the key features of a standard normal distribution is that it follows the empirical rule, which states:

 

 

Therefore, the percentage of data values that fall within one standard deviation of the mean in a standard normal distribution is approximately 68%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: A HIV patient is presenting with cough without sputum, on examination his CD4 counts were <100 and chest x ray shown bilateral infiltration of lung, on further proceeding Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the organisms were positive for acid fast staining, what is the organism responsible for his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium avium complex

 

Based on the clinical presentation, CD4 count, radiographic findings, and positive acid-fast staining in the bronchoalveolar lavage, the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition is Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a group of bacteria that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that commonly causes pneumonia in people with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS. However, the cough in this case is without sputum, which is not typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia. Although PCP is common in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL, it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus is a fungus that can cause a severe lung infection and meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with a positive acid-fast stain and is not commonly associated with lung infiltrates seen on chest X-rays in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL presenting with a cough without sputum, bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray, and positive acid-fast staining, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

 

The primary function of the proteasome is to degrade intracellular proteins. It plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by breaking down unneeded or damaged proteins. Proteins are targeted for degradation by being tagged with a small protein called ubiquitin, and the proteasome then recognizes and degrades these ubiquitinated proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein folding: The proteasome is not involved in protein folding. Protein folding is a process where newly synthesized proteins attain their three-dimensional, functional structures. It typically occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is assisted by chaperone proteins.

 

Option B. Post-translational modification: While some post-translational modifications of proteins can occur in the proteasome, its primary function is not post-translational modification. Post-translational modifications include processes like phosphorylation, glycosylation, and ubiquitination, which may occur on proteins both before and after they enter the proteasome.

 

Option D. Protein sorting: Protein sorting involves directing proteins to their correct cellular locations, such as organelles like the mitochondria or lysosomes. The proteasome's main function is not related to protein sorting but rather protein degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells. The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length

 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.    

 

It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

choices.text: Suicidal firearm wounds
Traumatic asphyxia
Drowning
Electrocution

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in all except: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Traumatic asphyxia

 

Option B. Traumatic Asphyxia : This condition typically results from a severe crush injury to the chest or abdomen that prevents normal respiration. Cadaveric spasms are less likely because the death does not involve a sudden catastrophic nervous system event that would induce immediate muscle contraction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Suicidal Firearm Wounds : Cadaveric spasm may occur in cases of suicidal firearm wounds due to the intense muscle contraction at the moment of death. The individual might be holding a weapon tightly, which can lead to a cadaveric spasm preserving the grip on the firearm.

 

Option C. Drowning : Cadaveric spasm can occur during drowning as the individual may be holding onto objects or vegetation in a panic, and these grips can become fixed due to the sudden cessation of brain function.

 

Option D. Electrocution : Electrocution can cause instantaneous and intense muscular contractions and possibly a cadaveric spasm. This can result in the deceased gripping onto any objects they were touching at the time of electrocution.

 

Educational objective :

 

Cadaveric spasm is a rare phenomenon usually associated with the sudden and intense activation of muscles at the time of death. It is most commonly seen in deaths involving intense emotional or physical stress where the muscle contraction occurs at or near the moment of death, such as in shootings, electrocution, or drowning.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma accuminata

 

  • Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).
  • The main causative agent is HPV-6 and 11.
  • Lesions: Typically, they grow in clusters along a narrow stalk giving it a cauliflower appearance but at times the stalk may be broad and thick
  • Treatment: Cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision or topical use of 5-fluorouracil, trichloro-acetic acid or intralesional interferon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum:

 

  • Caused by a pox virus transmitted by body contact or towels or clothing.
  • It is commonly seen in immunodeficient subject or with HIV infections.
  • The lesions vary in size up to 1 cm, dome shaped, pearly-white in colour and often umbilicated.
  • They are usually multiple and can occur anywhere in the skin and genitalia.
  • Microscopic appearance reveals numerous inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies) in the cytoplasm of the cells with Giemsa stain.
  • Treatment: 
    • Evacuation of caseous material from the nodule under local anaesthetic is done.
    • The floor of the nodule is then treated chemically with ferric sub-sulphate or trichloroacetic acid (85%) solution.
    • Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is applied until a halo of ice is formed around the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

 

 

Option D. Herpes:

 

  • The causative organism is herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2.
  • It is usually transmitted sexually by an infected partner/ oro-genital contact.
  • The incubation period is 2–14 days.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Initially, red painful inflammatory areas appear commonly on the clitoris, labia, vestibule, vagina, perineum, and cervix.
    • Multiple vesicles appear which progress into multiple shallow ulcers and ultimately heal up spontaneously by crusting.
    • It takes about 3 weeks to complete the process.
    • Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever, malaise, and headache.
    •  There may be vulvar burning, pruritus, dysuria, or retention of urine.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are characterized by multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, caused by HPV-6 and 11, and treated with cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical agents.

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

choices.text: Category A - Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents
Category C - Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B - Slow to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates

questions.text: According to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents, which one of the following statements is untrue? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

 

  • As per the CDC, bioterrorism agents are categorized solely into three groups, namely Category A, B, and C, with no classification for a Category D.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT

 

Macula densa are specialized cells in the end portion of thick ascending segment before it opens into distal convoluted tubule. It is situated between afferent and efferent arterioles of the same nephron. It is very close to afferent arteriole. Macula densa is formed by tightly packed cuboidal epithelial cells. It forms the part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of thick descending limb and DCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not located at the junction of the thick descending limb and the distal convoluted tubule.

 

Option B. Junction of thick descending limb and PCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not found at the junction of the thick descending limb and the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Option D. Junction of DCT and collecting duct: Incorrect. The macula densa is located before the DCT opens into the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa is composed of specialized cells located at the junction of the thick ascending limb and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), playing a crucial role in the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

questions.text: The most specific and typical sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

 

  • Gottron's papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The classical diagnostic criteria for Juvenile Dermatomyositis include the presence of Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Gottron's papules are identified as violaceous, lichenoid, inflammatory, flat-topped papules found on the extensor surfaces, particularly the knuckles ( proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints) as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitive skin rash:

 

  • While photosensitivity can be a feature in some patients with juvenile dermatomyositis, it is not the most specific sign.
  • Photosensitive rashes are also common in other conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) making it less specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nail bed capillary changes:

 

  • Nail bed capillary changes, such as dilated or drop-out capillaries, can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis as shown in the image below

 

 

  • However, these changes are also found in other connective tissue diseases, so they are not the most specific for juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Malar rash:

 

  • A malar rash, or "butterfly rash" as shown in the image below is typically associated with SLE, not juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

 

  • Although skin manifestations can overlap between different connective tissue diseases, a malar rash is not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gottron's papules are flat-topped, red or violaceous papules. They are considered pathognomonic (specifically indicative) of dermatomyositis and are one of the hallmark features of the disease and represent the most specific sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53, page nos. 53.4, 53.11

Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1182, 1183

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

choices.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother, is brought to a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred two days ago. The next course of action for the registered medical practitioner would be?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Take a detailed history

 

The next course of action involves the registered medical practitioner gathering a comprehensive medical history.

 

The registered medical professional must conduct a comprehensive medical history review and obtain informed consent before proceeding with the examination. If the individual declines the examination, a well-documented informed refusal must be obtained, clearly explaining the potential consequences of their decision.

 

During the examination process, the medical practitioner should gather necessary specimens, preserve any relevant clothing, and meticulously document all injuries and findings. It is essential to provide free medical treatment and conduct pregnancy testing for all victims of sexual assault, as mandated by law under section 357-C of CrPc. Additionally, the police must be notified accordingly.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Preserve clothing: Preserving clothing is essential for forensic evidence but should follow after taking a detailed history to ensure the context is understood and evidence is collected appropriately.

 

Option C: Take consent for genital examination: Taking consent for a genital examination is critical but must come after obtaining a detailed history to ensure the examination is conducted respectfully and with full understanding of the context.

 

Option D: Documentation of injuries and examination findings: Documentation of injuries and examination findings is vital for forensic and medical records but should be done after taking a detailed history and obtaining informed consent.

 

Educational Objective

 

In cases of alleged sexual violence, the initial and crucial step for the registered medical practitioner is to take a detailed history from the victim.

questions.text: Philadelphia chromosome is caused by translocation of which of the following chromosomes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 22 and 9

 

Explanation:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t (9;22) (q34;q11). This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9, creating the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.

 

The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, which is responsible for the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of myeloid cells in CML. The enhanced tyrosine kinase activity of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein leads to the development of this malignancy.

 

The specific involvement of the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22 in the translocation can be denoted as t(9q;22q) or t(9;22)(q34;q11), where 'q' represents the long arm, and '34' and '11' represent the specific bands on the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, respectively, where the breakpoints occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, the hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase responsible for the development of CML.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

questions.text: Paris green powder is used for killing of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anopheles larva

 

Paris green powder is a chemical compound known as copper acetoarsenate, which is used as an anti-larval agent in the control of mosquito populations, under National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, India.

 

The mechanism of action of Paris green is that it acts as a stomach poison when ingested by the larvae. This disrupts the normal biological functions of the larvae, effectively killing them before they can mature into adult mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria parasite: Paris green powder does not target the malaria parasite directly. Instead, it targets the mosquito larvae, which are vectors for the parasite.

 

Option C. Mites: Paris green powder is not effective against mites; it is specifically used against mosquito larvae.

 

Option D. Adult mosquito: While there are chemical agents such as DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion that are used to target adult mosquitoes. These adulticides work as nerve or contact poisons, inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme in adult mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antilarval measures: Paris green – 2% dust applied in dose of 1 kg per hectare; ‘stomach poison’ to larvae but harmless to humans, animals or fish

 

Antiadult measures: DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

Explanation:

 

This instrument is Wrigley’s (Outlet) Forceps.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kielland’s Forceps: Slight pelvic curve, rotational forceps

 

Option B. Pipers Forceps: After coming head of breech, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks for the body to rest on

 

Option D. Das Forceps: It is an Indian type of long Obstetric forceps, lighter than its western counterparts, may be available with axis traction device

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrigley's (Outlet) Forceps are used for assisted vaginal delivery when the fetal head is at the perineum.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8thedition page 652,659

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Miliary tuberculosis

 

The above image represents “miliary tuberculosis”. Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma.

 

Miliary tuberculosis is lymphohematogenous spread of tuberculous infection from primary focus or later stages of tuberculosis. The spread may occur to systemic organs or isolated organ. The spread is either by entry of infection into pulmonary vein producing disseminated or isolated organ lesion in different extra-pulmonary sites (e.g. liver, spleen, kidney, brain and bone marrow) or into pulmonary artery restricting the development of miliary lesions within the lung. The miliary lesions are millet seed-sized (1 mm diameter), yellowish, firm areas without grossly visible caseation necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emphysema: This condition is characterized by the abnormal, permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles and the destruction of the alveolar walls. Large subpleural bullae (air-filled spaces >1 cm) may be present, especially in paraseptal emphysema.

 

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Typically presents with non-caseating granulomas.

 

 

Option D. Asbestosis: Associated with fibrous thickening and plaque formation primarily in the lung bases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis appears as small, millet seed-sized yellowish foci scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, indicative of widespread hematogenous dissemination of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Highest thermic effect?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Proteins have the highest thermic effect among the three macronutrients. When you consume protein-rich foods, your body needs to expend more energy to break down and process the proteins. This is because proteins are composed of amino acids, and the body requires energy to convert them into usable forms. The thermic effect of proteins ranges from 20% to 30% of the total caloric intake from protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect. The thermic effect of carbohydrates ranges from 5% to 10% of the total caloric intake from carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Fats: Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients. The thermic effect of fats ranges from 0% to 5% of the total caloric intake from fats.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are the building blocks of fats, and their thermic effect is similar to that of fats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: Visual blurring in papilledema is called as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amaurosis fugax

 

Explanation:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring or vision loss.

 

It is often seen in conditions where there is temporary reduction in blood flow to the eye, such as in papilledema. Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head (optic disc) due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling can cause transient visual disturbances, which are described as amaurosis fugax.

 

In papilledema, the optic nerve head becomes swollen due to stasis of axoplasmic flow, often because of compression or increased pressure on the optic nerve. Despite this swelling, optic nerve function remains normal initially, meaning that central vision, color vision, and pupil reactions are typically preserved. The transient visual blurring episodes (amaurosis fugax) are a key symptom.

                       

Note - Finding in visual field charting (Papilledema)– enlargement of physiological blind spot

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blindness: This refers to complete loss of vision, which is not the case in papilledema where vision disturbances are transient.

 

Option C. Malingering: This term refers to the intentional feigning of illness or symptoms for secondary gain, and is not related to the visual disturbances seen in papilledema.

 

Option D. Corectopia: This is a condition where the pupil is displaced from its normal central position. It is unrelated to the transient visual blurring seen in papilledema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring seen in conditions like papilledema, which is characterized by swelling of the optic nerve head due to increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

 

While it is commonly believed that femoral hernias are the most frequent type of hernia in females, this is not the case. The most common type of hernia in both males and females is the inguinal hernia, specifically the indirect inguinal hernia.

 

Inguinal hernias occur due to a weakness in the abdominal wall and the presence of a natural opening, the deep inguinal ring. Indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through this deep ring, are particularly common. Although femoral hernias are more commonly seen in women than in men, their overall incidence is much lower compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal: This type of hernia is less common than indirect inguinal hernias and occurs due to weakness in the floor of the inguinal canal. It is not the most common type in females.

 

Option C. Femoral: Although more common in women than in men, femoral hernias have a much lower overall incidence compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Obturator: This is a rare type of hernia and is not commonly seen in the general population, including females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of hernia in females, as in males, is the indirect inguinal hernia. Despite the misconception, femoral hernias, though more common in women than men, are less frequent overall.

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VII

 

The factor marked as 'L' is factor VII, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.

 

 

Thrombin also activates factor XIlI, which is the fibrin stabilizing factor to factor XIlla. This factor XIlla forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII: Involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Works as a cofactor for Factor IXa in the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option D. VWF (Von Willebrand Factor): Involved in platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII but is not involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for adults:

 

  • Spontaneous breathing = Mapleson A or Magill's circuit
  • Controlled breathing = Mapleson D or Bain's circuit

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for pediatrics – Mapleson F circuit

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults is Mapleson A.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 613

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

choices.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement
To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

 

Incorrect. While a frozen section can provide rapid results, it does not replace the need for a formal and thorough pathological examination of paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The frozen section technique can sometimes result in artifacts that make interpretation challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine sentinel lymph node involvement: Correct. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed during breast cancer surgery, and a frozen section of the node can be examined to determine if there's cancerous involvement. If positive, complete axillary lymph node clearance can be done.

 

Option B. To assess margin positivity: Correct. During breast-conserving surgeries, the surgeon aims to remove the tumor along with a rim of normal tissue. A frozen section can be used to immediately check if the margins (edges) of the removed tissue are free of cancer cells. If cancer cells are found at the margin, additional tissue can be removed during the same procedure.

 

Option C. To evaluate metastasis: Correct. The frozen section can be used to evaluate if there's metastasis to the lymph nodes or other tissues sampled during the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient underwent cholecystectomy and subsequently complained of pain in the legs after walking for some distance. Which investigation would be most appropriate for further evaluation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan 

 

The patient's symptoms suggest occurrence of post operative Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The investigations listed are used to evaluate vascular conditions:

 

This ultrasound-based diagnostic technique combines traditional ultrasound to visualize the structure of the blood vessels and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow within the vessels. It is the first-line investigation for DVT as it is non-invasive, widely available, and cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that visualizes blood vessels. It is a good non-invasive option to visualize blood flow and vascular anatomy but is less commonly used as a first-line test due to cost and availability.

 

Option C. CT angiography: This imaging modality uses computed tomography (CT) combined with a contrast agent to visualize vascular structures. It's useful in detailed mapping of blood vessels but exposes the patient to radiation and contrast, which may not be suitable for all patients.

 

Option D. USG: Ultrasound (USG) is useful for various diagnostic purposes but on its own may not be sufficient for a full vascular assessment in the case of DVT unless it's part of a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a morbidly obese patient presenting with leg pain consistent with DVT post-cholecystectomy, a duplex scan is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate for DVT.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

 

Gastric lavage, also known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, involves the removal of the stomach's contents via a tube. It is contraindicated in certain situations due to the risks involved.

 

Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine is a convulsive poison. Performing gastric lavage on a patient with strychnine poisoning is highly dangerous because it can induce further convulsions and seizures. Gastric lavage acts as a stimulus, which can exacerbate the convulsions, leading to a higher risk of complications including aspiration of stomach contents into the lungs.

 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

 

  • Corrosive substances (an absolute C/I): Risk of gastric perforation except for carbolic acid, which hardens the stomach wall.
  • Convulsive patients: Risk of aspiration.
  • Comatose patients: Also at risk of aspiration unless the airway is protected.
  • Kerosene & other volatile poison, including hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons are volatile and can cause chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Oesophageal Varices

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ingestion of paraldehyde: Paraldehyde ingestion does not have the same risk of inducing convulsions or seizures. Gastric lavage can be considered in some cases, but it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ingestion of hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons, such as kerosene, are volatile and pose a high risk of aspiration leading to chemical pneumonitis. While this is also a contraindication, the most critical contraindication here is strychnine poisoning due to the additional risk of inducing seizures.

 

Option D. Iron tablet ingestion: Iron tablets do not pose a high risk of convulsions or severe aspiration. Gastric lavage can be used in cases of iron tablet ingestion if done early and under proper medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Only

 

The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive Aspergillosis

 

Galactomannan (GM) belongs to a group of polysaccharides which consist of a mannose backbone and a variable number of galactofuran side chains. GM makes up a major part of the cell wall of Aspergillus spp. These galactofuranose-containing polysaccharides vary are secreted in vivo by the fungus during invasive growth. In recent years, the detection of galactofuranose-containing antigens, including GM, has been used for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA).

 

The most commonly used method to determine GM in serum and broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is a double sandwich enzyme-linked immune assay

 

Other Fungal Infections:

 

2. Systemic Candidiasis: Does not typically involve the release of galactomannan.

 

3. Mucormycosis: Caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, which do not produce  galactomannan. It has beta-D-Glucans and mannans that can be used for diagnosis of invasive candidiasis.

 

4. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus species, and the detection of its polysaccharide capsule antigen (cryptococcal antigen) is used for diagnosis, not galactomannan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galactomannan assay is specifically used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, and the presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of this fungal infection.

questions.text: All of the following are responsible for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INF- y  

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is associated with a transient, marked rise in circulating tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF alpha), interleukin 6 (IL-6) and interleukin 8 (IL-8).

 

It is an inflammatory reaction that can occur after treatment for syphilis.

 

The symptoms usually begin 2 hours from the administration of the antibiotic and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TNF alpha: Directly involved in the inflammatory response associated with JHR.

 

Option B. IL-6: Also directly involved in JHR, promoting inflammatory processes.

 

Option C. IL-8: Plays a role in recruiting neutrophils to sites of infection, contributing to the inflammatory reaction in JHR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is primarily driven by a surge in pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF alpha, IL-6, and IL-8, but not by INF-γ.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next best step of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

 

Given patient with fever and filarial antigen test positive points to diagnosis of filariasis. And the next best step for this patient is the detection of microfilariae in the blood smear.

 

The gold standard method to diagnose active infection is by demonstrating microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopy.

 

It is critical and should be based on the periodicity of the microfilariae. For nocturnal periodicity, blood should be collected between 9 pm and 2 am.

 

DEC provocation test is done to collect the blood in the day time. Patient takes a tablet of DEC orally (2mg/kg) so that the nocturnal microfilariae are stimulated and come to peripheral blood within 30 minutes.

 

Although there is an advantage of blood sample collection even during day time, the guidelines from CDC, NVBDCP, and IAPSM suggest blood sample collection at night, followed by identification of microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopic examination as the standard method for diagnosis.

 

Other methods to detect adult worms include:

 

  • Lymph node biopsy to detect adult worms.
  • X-ray (if worms are calcified)
  • High-frequency ultrasound and doppler of the scrotum (Option D).
  • Serology - Antigen detection by using monoclonal antibodies against Og4C3 and AD12 antigens.
  • ELISA and ICT

 

Treatment - Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) → DOC. Given orally in a dose of 6 mg per kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days. It kills microfilariae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone Marrow Biopsy: Not relevant for filariasis, as it does not involve the bone marrow.

 

Option B. DEC Provocation Test: While useful for driving microfilariae into the peripheral blood for easier detection during daytime, it is less direct than a nighttime blood smear.

 

Option D. Ultrasound of the Scrotum: Useful in chronic cases to detect adult worms in lymphatic vessels, particularly in cases of lymphatic filariasis affecting the scrotum, but not as immediate or definitive for acute diagnosis as a blood smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct confirmation of active filarial infection, detection of microfilariae in a blood smear is essential. This method provides clear evidence of the parasites in the bloodstream, crucial for diagnosing and managing filariasis effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism. Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: How much is the distance between the victim and the firearm from the gunshot entry based on the wound given below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Close Contact

 

The image provided shows a gunshot wound with visible tattooing (stippling) around the wound. Tattooing is caused by the impact of unburnt gunpowder particles striking the skin. In close contact range wounds, singeing, blackening, and tattooing are typically seen around the wound, indicating the gun was fired from a very short distance, but not directly pressed against the skin.

 

In this question, since tattooing is visible around the wound without evidence of singeing or blackening directly at the wound margins, it aligns with characteristics of a close contact shot. Ideally, if "Intermediate Range" was an option, it would fit better because it specifically involves tattooing without other signs like singeing and blackening; however, given the choices, close contact remains the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact Entry: In contact range, the muzzle of the firearm is directly against the skin, causing blackening, singeing, and tattooing only at the margins of the wound, not around it. This differs from what is seen in the image, ruling this option out.

 

Option C. Distant Range: In distant range wounds, there are no signs of singeing, blackening, or tattooing around the entry wound, as the gunpowder does not reach the skin. The presence of tattooing makes this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. Cannot be predicted: This option is incorrect because the presence of tattooing around the wound provides specific information about the distance between the firearm and the victim, allowing us to make an informed decision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing (stippling) around a gunshot wound indicates a close contact or intermediate range. The absence of singeing or blackening suggests the firearm was not in direct contact but was fired from a short distance, such as close contact.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

 

The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the rapid onset of painful urethral discharge are highly indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal urethritis typically presents with dysuria (painful urination) and a purulent (pus-like) discharge from the urethra.

 

The treatment of choice for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This treatment is preferred due to its efficacy in eradicating the infection and its convenience as a single-dose therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 2 weeks: Doxycycline is typically used for treating chlamydial infections, which can co-occur with gonorrhea but is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea itself. Additionally, a two-week course is usually prescribed for chlamydia, not gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Benzathine Penicillin: Benzathine Penicillin is primarily used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhea. Syphilis and gonorrhea are different sexually transmitted infections with distinct treatments.

 

Option D. Azithromycin 1 gm stat: Azithromycin can be used in the treatment of chlamydial infections, often alongside treatment for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection. However, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea when given alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery
